repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
*See [Is Includes/cpython/datetime.pxd incomplete?](https://groups.google.com/u/1/g/cython-users/c/d4zOq6i7D9M)*

I used the other code in that file as a reference point, but as I did that I noticed how it doesn't actually fully conform to [CPython's `datetime.h` file](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Include/datetime.h), for example see the following: https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/3048be77631d91ddf9210c34f8de436ab70d7c04/Cython/Includes/cpython/datetime.pxd#L156-L157 Compared to CPython's `.h` file:
https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/49fdf118aeda891401d638ac32296c7d55d54678/Include/datetime.h#L226-L228

*I could widen the scope of this pull request to include making the necessary changes for that.*


**For the additions I have done so far, am I supposed to add tests for them?**

comment_data.body:
That's not using the right signature. According to `datetime.h`, it's called like this:
```c
    PyDateTimeAPI->DateTime_FromTimestamp( \
        (PyObject*) (PyDateTimeAPI->DateTimeType), args, NULL)
```
where `args` is a tuple. So, I guess, the equivalent in Cython would be
```suggestion
# Create a datetime object using DateTime CAPI classmethod.
cdef inline object datetime_from_timestamp(timestamp, tz=None):
    return PyDateTimeApi.DateTime_FromTimestamp(
        PyDateTimeApi.DateTimeType, (timestamp, tz) if tz is not None else (timestamp,), NULL)
```
That suggests that the signature of that function pointer (`(object, object, object)`) is incorrect. It should be `(PyTypeObject*, object, PyObject*)`. Which … looks ugly, but that's how it's used.

Similarly, the function below also wants an `args` tuple as argument, not a float. (And, BTW, `float` means C float, not Python float.)

It doesn't really feel like these will be much faster than a plain Python call. Probably still visible in really time critical code, I guess.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +167,14 @@ cdef inline object datetime_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minu
 cdef inline object timedelta_new(int days, int seconds, int useconds):
     return PyDateTimeAPI.Delta_FromDelta(days, seconds, useconds, 1, PyDateTimeAPI.DeltaType)
 
+# Create a datetime object using DateTime CAPI classmethod.
+cdef inline object datetime_from_timestamp(float timestamp, object tz):
+    return PyDateTimeApi.DateTime_FromTimestamp(timestamp, tz)

comment_data.body:
> (And, BTW, float means C float, not Python float.)

 Is that why you removed the `float` static typing from timestamp? Shouldn't there be `int` then, or is it just better without typing?

The documentation specifies:
> Return the local date and time corresponding to the POSIX timestamp, such as is returned by [time.time()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html#time.time).

> time.time() → float
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +167,14 @@ cdef inline object datetime_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minu
 cdef inline object timedelta_new(int days, int seconds, int useconds):
     return PyDateTimeAPI.Delta_FromDelta(days, seconds, useconds, 1, PyDateTimeAPI.DeltaType)
 
+# Create a datetime object using DateTime CAPI classmethod.
+cdef inline object datetime_from_timestamp(float timestamp, object tz):
+    return PyDateTimeApi.DateTime_FromTimestamp(timestamp, tz)

comment_data.body:
> Is that why you removed the float static typing from timestamp? Shouldn't there be int then, or is it just better without typing?

Since we're only using it as an object, we shouldn't require users to pass in a C value. They may already have an object on their side that we can just pass through. Or they may not, in which case the conversion will happen automatically on the caller side. Taking an object and passing it on is as fast as it gets.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +167,14 @@ cdef inline object datetime_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minu
 cdef inline object timedelta_new(int days, int seconds, int useconds):
     return PyDateTimeAPI.Delta_FromDelta(days, seconds, useconds, 1, PyDateTimeAPI.DeltaType)
 
+# Create a datetime object using DateTime CAPI classmethod.
+cdef inline object datetime_from_timestamp(float timestamp, object tz):
+    return PyDateTimeApi.DateTime_FromTimestamp(timestamp, tz)

comment_data.body:
This can't work because we haven't imported the C-API yet at this point, i.e. the user did not call `import_datetime()` yet.

Also, it requires a cast to `<object>`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -141,6 +149,9 @@ cdef extern from "datetime.h":
 cdef inline void import_datetime():
     PyDateTime_IMPORT
 
+# Time zone singleton for UTC.
+cdef object utc_tz = PyDateTimeAPI.TimeZone_UTC

comment_data.body:
"optionally" suggests to me that it should be … optional. :)
```suggestion
# Create a timezone from an offset, optionally a name.
cdef inline object timezone_from_offset(offset, name=None):
    return PyDateTimeAPI.TimeZone_FromTimeZone(offset, NULL if name is None else <PyObject*>name)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +172,27 @@ cdef inline object datetime_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minu
 cdef inline object timedelta_new(int days, int seconds, int useconds):
     return PyDateTimeAPI.Delta_FromDelta(days, seconds, useconds, 1, PyDateTimeAPI.DeltaType)
 
+# Create a timezone from an offset, optionally a name.
+cdef inline object timezone_new(offset, name):
+    return PyDateTimeAPI.TimeZone_FromTimeZone(offset, name)

comment_data.body: `fold` defaults to `0`. If it wasn't added only in Py3.6 and later, we could simply make it an optional argument to the existing `datetime_new()` function. However, the fact that the `…AndFold()` C-API functions are not available at all in Py<3.6 requires a bit of C macro magic to make this compile in older Pythons.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +172,27 @@ cdef inline object datetime_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minu
 cdef inline object timedelta_new(int days, int seconds, int useconds):
     return PyDateTimeAPI.Delta_FromDelta(days, seconds, useconds, 1, PyDateTimeAPI.DeltaType)
 
+# Create a timezone from an offset, optionally a name.
+cdef inline object timezone_new(offset, name):
+    return PyDateTimeAPI.TimeZone_FromTimeZone(offset, name)
+
+# Create a datetime object with a fold using DateTime CAPI factory function.
+cdef inline object datetime_and_fold_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minute, int second, int microsecond, object tz, int fold):
+    return PyDateTimeAPI.DateTime_FromDateAndTimeAndFold(year, month, day, hour, minute, second, microsecond, tz, fold, PyDateTimeAPI.DateTimeType)

comment_data.body: Ah! That's what I was missing, so make that a function like `get_utc()` and then do that cast. Gotcha
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -141,6 +149,9 @@ cdef extern from "datetime.h":
 cdef inline void import_datetime():
     PyDateTime_IMPORT
 
+# Time zone singleton for UTC.
+cdef object utc_tz = PyDateTimeAPI.TimeZone_UTC

comment_data.body: I was originally thinking that the optionality would end up in the C Api's hands, which does have a default. Good catch.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +172,27 @@ cdef inline object datetime_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minu
 cdef inline object timedelta_new(int days, int seconds, int useconds):
     return PyDateTimeAPI.Delta_FromDelta(days, seconds, useconds, 1, PyDateTimeAPI.DeltaType)
 
+# Create a timezone from an offset, optionally a name.
+cdef inline object timezone_new(offset, name):
+    return PyDateTimeAPI.TimeZone_FromTimeZone(offset, name)

comment_data.body:
Are you proposing that something similar to what was done earlier in the file is done? I am referencing the following bit of code (in the doc-strings):

```
    """
    #if PY_MAJOR_VERSION < 3 && !defined(PyDateTime_DELTA_GET_DAYS)
    #define PyDateTime_DELTA_GET_DAYS(o)         (((PyDateTime_Delta*)o)->days)
    #endif
    #if PY_MAJOR_VERSION < 3 && !defined(PyDateTime_DELTA_GET_SECONDS)
    #define PyDateTime_DELTA_GET_SECONDS(o)      (((PyDateTime_Delta*)o)->seconds)
    #endif
    #if PY_MAJOR_VERSION < 3 && !defined(PyDateTime_DELTA_GET_MICROSECONDS)
    #define PyDateTime_DELTA_GET_MICROSECONDS(o)   (((PyDateTime_Delta*)o)->microseconds)
    #endif
    """
```

This should probably be done for the upcoming `get_utc()` function then as well?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +172,27 @@ cdef inline object datetime_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minu
 cdef inline object timedelta_new(int days, int seconds, int useconds):
     return PyDateTimeAPI.Delta_FromDelta(days, seconds, useconds, 1, PyDateTimeAPI.DeltaType)
 
+# Create a timezone from an offset, optionally a name.
+cdef inline object timezone_new(offset, name):
+    return PyDateTimeAPI.TimeZone_FromTimeZone(offset, name)
+
+# Create a datetime object with a fold using DateTime CAPI factory function.
+cdef inline object datetime_and_fold_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minute, int second, int microsecond, object tz, int fold):
+    return PyDateTimeAPI.DateTime_FromDateAndTimeAndFold(year, month, day, hour, minute, second, microsecond, tz, fold, PyDateTimeAPI.DateTimeType)

comment_data.body:
Yes. We'd define them as an alias to the non-`AndFold` functions, for anything before 3.6(beta? – or whenever it was added).

Not sure if we should make it an error if a non-0 value is passed, but I'd rather not. It seems reasonable for user code to ignore this case, without special treatment. Making it an error, while making it visible that the case is not handled correctly, would also require the users who do not care to add special-casing code on their side.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -161,6 +172,27 @@ cdef inline object datetime_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minu
 cdef inline object timedelta_new(int days, int seconds, int useconds):
     return PyDateTimeAPI.Delta_FromDelta(days, seconds, useconds, 1, PyDateTimeAPI.DeltaType)
 
+# Create a timezone from an offset, optionally a name.
+cdef inline object timezone_new(offset, name):
+    return PyDateTimeAPI.TimeZone_FromTimeZone(offset, name)
+
+# Create a datetime object with a fold using DateTime CAPI factory function.
+cdef inline object datetime_and_fold_new(int year, int month, int day, int hour, int minute, int second, int microsecond, object tz, int fold):
+    return PyDateTimeAPI.DateTime_FromDateAndTimeAndFold(year, month, day, hour, minute, second, microsecond, tz, fold, PyDateTimeAPI.DateTimeType)

comment_data.body: I haven't really had time to figure it out completely and test, but thought I'd push a form of "status rapport", is this somewhat what we've been talking about?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -76,22 +76,40 @@ cdef extern from "datetime.h":
 
     # Define structure for C API.
     ctypedef struct PyDateTime_CAPI:
+        """
+        #if PY_MAJOR_VERSON < 3 && PY_MINOR_VERSION < 6 && !defined(*DateTime_FromDateAndTimeAndFold)
+        #define DateTime_FromDateAndTimeAndFold(year, month, day, hour, min, sec, usec, tz, fold) \
+        #   PyDateTimeAPI->DateTime_FromDateAndTime(year, month, day, hour, min, sec, usec, tz)
+        #endif
+        #if Py_MAJOR_VERSION < 3 && PY_MINOR_VERSION < 6 && !defined(*Time_FromTimeAndFold)
+        #define PyTime_FromTimeAndFold(hour, minute, second, usecond, fold) \
+        #   PydateTimeAPI->Time_FromTime(hour, minute, second, usecond)
+        #endif
+        """
